title: First Aid Procedures

procedures.name: CPR

adults: Ensure the scene is safe before approaching.
If unresponsive and not breathing normally, call emergency services immediately.
Kneel beside the person on a firm surface and position their head for an open airway.
Give 30 chest compressions (at least 2 inches deep at 100–120/min), then give 2 rescue breaths (tilt head, pinch nose, make a seal).
Continue cycles of 30 compressions and 2 breaths until the person shows signs of life or help arrives.
children_infants: For a child or infant who is unresponsive and not breathing, follow the same procedure.
Call emergency services immediately, then begin CPR with 30 chest compressions and 2 breaths.
For a child (about age 1–8), use one hand for compressions; for an infant (<1 year), use two fingers in the center of the chest.
Deliver compressions at about 100–120 per minute, compressing to one-third the chest depth.
Continue CPR cycles (about 5 cycles/2 minutes) before pausing only to call EMS if alone.

key_precautions: Ensure the scene is safe and wear gloves or a barrier device for rescue breaths.
Do not delay CPR to get help – if alone, give 2 minutes of CPR (5 cycles) before calling emergency services.
Minimize interruptions during compressions.
If breaths do not cause chest rise, retilt head and retry (an airway obstruction may be present).
when_to_call_emergency: Call emergency services before starting CPR if possible (someone else should call while you give care).
Always call if the person is unresponsive or not breathing normally.

procedures.name: Choking

adults_and_children: Encourage the person to cough if they can speak or cough.
If they cannot breathe or cough effectively, deliver up to 5 back blows between the shoulder blades (bend them forward and firm blows).
If still choking, perform up to 5 abdominal thrusts (Heimlich maneuver): stand behind, wrap arms around waist, make a fist above the navel, and thrust inward and upward.
Alternate back blows and thrusts until the object is expelled.
If the person becomes unconscious, carefully lower them to the ground and begin CPR (each time before breaths, look for and remove the object if seen).
infants_under_1_year: Place the baby face-down on your forearm (supporting head).
Give 5 gentle back blows between the shoulder blades with the heel of your hand.
If still choking, turn the infant face-up and give 5 chest thrusts (2 fingers in center of chest, 1.5 inches deep).
Repeat back blows and chest thrusts as needed.
If the infant becomes unresponsive, begin infant CPR (30 compressions/2 breaths) immediately.

key_precautions: Do not perform abdominal thrusts on very small children or babies – use back blows and chest thrusts instead.
Do not do blind finger sweeps in a conscious person.
If the object is visible in the mouth, remove it with a hook (do not push it deeper).
Ensure airway clearance before rescue breaths.
when_to_call_emergency: Call emergency services if choking is not relieved quickly, the person becomes unconscious, or if they show any distress (blue lips, extreme panic).
If alone and the person is choking severely, call EMS immediately and then give self-Heimlich by pressing abdomen against a chair.

procedures.name: Heart Attack
step_by_step_first_aid: Call emergency services immediately.
Help the person to sit in a comfortable, slightly reclined position and reassure them.
If they chew aspirin and have no allergy, give one adult dose (300 mg) to chew (this can help).
If prescribed nitroglycerin and available, assist them to take it under the tongue.
Loosen tight clothing and monitor breathing.
Be ready to perform CPR if they become unresponsive.
key_precautions: Do not allow them to exert themselves.
Do not give them food or drink (in case surgery is needed).
Check for allergies before giving aspirin or medication.
If unconscious, do NOT attempt to give anything by mouth.
when_to_call_emergency: Always call emergency services for chest pain lasting more than a few minutes, especially if it radiates to arm/jaw, or is accompanied by shortness of breath, nausea, or lightheadedness.
If the person loses consciousness or stops breathing, start CPR and call EMS.

procedures.name: Stroke
step_by_step_first_aid: Recognize stroke signs with FAST: Face droop, Arm weakness, Speech difficulty.
If any sign is positive, call emergency services immediately.
Keep the person calm and still; lay them down with head and shoulders slightly elevated, and cover with a blanket to keep warm.
Do not give them any food, drink, or medication.
If conscious, note the time symptoms began (very important for treatments).
key_precautions: Do not drive them to the hospital yourself – wait for professional help.
Do not let them sleep or become inactive.
Loosen tight clothing to help breathing.
when_to_call_emergency: Immediately at first suspicion of stroke.
Call EMS at once if the person shows face droop, arm weakness, or slurred speech. Time is critical in stroke.

procedures.name: Severe Bleeding
step_by_step_first_aid: Don gloves if available.
Expose the wound (cut or tear of skin) and apply firm, direct pressure with a clean cloth or sterile gauze.
Keep pressing until bleeding stops.
If possible, elevate the injured area above heart level to slow bleeding.
If blood soaks through, do not remove the first cloth – add more cloth on top and continue pressure.
If bleeding is from a limb and will not stop, a tourniquet above the wound can be applied (only if trained and as a last resort).
Keep the person lying down, cover them to prevent shock, and wait for help.
key_precautions: Do not remove any embedded object – apply pressure around it.
Do not press on an open chest wound or an eye.
Avoid moving the person if broken bones may be present.
Do not use a tourniquet unless absolutely necessary (life-threatening limb bleed).
Keep the person calm.
when_to_call_emergency: Immediately if bleeding is large, spurting (arterial), or will not stop with pressure.
Also call EMS for head, neck, chest, or abdominal bleeding, or any sign of shock (pale, cold, rapid breathing).

procedures.name: Burns (1st, 2nd, 3rd degree)
step_by_step_first_aid: Stop the burning process by removing the person from heat or flame.
Remove any jewelry or tight clothing near the burn, unless it’s stuck to the burn.
Cool the burn with cool (not cold) running water for at least 20 minutes.
For 1st–2nd degree (superficial to partial-thickness) burns, after cooling cover loosely with sterile cling film or clean non-fluffy dressing.
For large or deep burns (especially 3rd degree), do NOT immerse too much – cover with clean cloth and call emergency services.
key_precautions: Do not apply ice, creams, butter or ointments.
Do not break blisters.
Do not remove clothing that is stuck to the burn.
Keep the person warm (prevent shock) but avoid overheating them.
Avoid using adhesive dressings on burn.
when_to_call_emergency: For any 3rd-degree burn, burns larger than a person’s hand size, or burns on face/hands/feet/genitals.
Also call if the person shows shock or the burn is chemical/electrical.
Infants, the elderly, or if you’re unsure, call for help.

procedures.name: Fractures (Broken Bones)
step_by_step_first_aid: Treat any bleeding first, then immobilize the injured limb.
Keep the person still.
Support the broken bone in the position found (do not try to realign it).
You can apply a splint: brace or padded board or rolled newspaper to keep bone from moving (tie above and below fracture).
Apply ice pack (wrapped in cloth) to reduce swelling.
Help the person lie down; raise the injured limb and support it, if no other injuries conflict.
key_precautions: Do not press on protruding bone or push it back in.
Do not move the person unless necessary (e.g. to avoid danger).
Avoid unnecessary movement of the limb.
If you must move them (for safety), try to keep the spine straight and support the injury.
when_to_call_emergency: Call EMS if any of the following: bone protruding through skin, severe deformity, unstable vital signs, open wound with fracture, heavy bleeding, numbness/tingling below injury, severe pain, or suspected spinal break.
For minor (closed, non-bleeding) fractures, seek medical care soon.

procedures.name: Sprains and Strains
step_by_step_first_aid: Have the person stop using the injured joint and rest.
Apply an ice pack wrapped in cloth to the area for up to 10 minutes.
Compress the injury with an elastic bandage (but not too tight) and elevate the limb to reduce swelling.
Let the person sit or lie down to rest the limb.
key_precautions: Do not apply heat or massage the injured area in the first 48 hours.
Do not keep ice on longer than 10 minutes.
If bandaging, avoid cutting off circulation – loosen if tingling/numb.
Give pain relief (ibuprofen/acetaminophen) if trained and no allergy.
when_to_call_emergency: Usually sprains can be managed at home.
However, if you suspect a broken bone (bone fracture signs) or the person cannot move the limb at all, or if there is severe deformity or the pain/swelling worsens, seek professional help.
If in doubt, treat as possible fracture and get medical care.

procedures.name: Shock
step_by_step_first_aid: If the person shows signs of shock (pale, cold sweat, rapid pulse, altered consciousness), call emergency services immediately.
Lay the person flat on their back.
If no head/neck injury is suspected, elevate the legs about 12 inches to improve blood flow to the heart and brain.
Control any bleeding and treat the cause (e.g., injury, allergic reaction).
Cover them with a blanket to keep warm.
key_precautions: Do not let them get chilled or too hot.
Loosen tight clothing.
Do not give food or drink (they may vomit).
Monitor breathing and consciousness; if breathing stops, begin CPR.
Stay with the person and reassure them.
when_to_call_emergency: Immediately if shock is suspected.
Any cause of shock (severe bleeding, severe allergic reaction, etc.) warrants EMS.
Do not delay calling for any signs of shock.

procedures.name: Hypothermia
step_by_step_first_aid: Move the person out of the cold into a warm place.
Remove any wet clothing and replace with dry, warm layers or blankets.
Cover the head.
Provide warm drinks (non-alcoholic) if they are fully conscious.
Warm the center of the body first: use warm (not hot) compresses on neck, chest, and groin.
key_precautions: Do not rewarm too rapidly (no hot baths or heating pads).
Do not rub or massage extremities (can drive cold blood to core).
Avoid alcohol or caffeine.
Be gentle – hypothermic people can go into cardiac arrest if moved roughly.
when_to_call_emergency: Call emergency services if core temperature is very low, or if the person is drowsy, confused, or not shivering (signs of moderate/severe hypothermia).
If any doubt about severity, seek medical care promptly.

procedures.name: Heat Exhaustion and Heatstroke

heat_exhaustion: Move the person to a cool, shaded place and have them lie down.
Cool them by fanning and applying cool, wet cloths or spraying with cool water.
Give sips of cool water or electrolyte drink (no alcohol/caffeine) if fully conscious.
Elevate the feet slightly and loosen clothing.
heatstroke: Call emergency services immediately if heatstroke is suspected (hot, flushed skin; confusion; very high temperature).
Move the person out of heat quickly.
Start aggressive cooling: pour cool water over them, immerse in cool water if possible, or place ice packs at neck/armpits/groin.
Do not give alcohol or caffeinated drinks.

heat_exhaustion: Do not force food or water if they are vomiting or unconscious.
Monitor for worsening (e.g. confusion or persistent vomiting).
heatstroke: Heatstroke can be deadly. Do not ignore symptoms.
Avoid overheating a person (stop cooling if shivering starts).

when_to_call_emergency: Heatstroke: Immediately – call EMS as soon as possible.
Heat exhaustion: Call if the person faints, has a seizure, or doesn’t improve with rest and cooling.

procedures.name: Seizures
step_by_step_first_aid: Stay calm and ensure the person is safe.
Lay them on their side (recovery position) to keep airway clear.
Cushion their head with something soft.
Remove nearby hazards (sharp objects, furniture).
Time the seizure.
key_precautions: Do not restrain the person or put anything in their mouth.
Do not give them anything to eat or drink until fully alert.
Loosen tight clothing.
If they vomit, turn head to side.
when_to_call_emergency: Call emergency services if the seizure lasts more than 5 minutes, or if multiple seizures occur back-to-back.
Also call if it’s their first seizure, if they do not regain consciousness, if breathing is abnormal, or if they are injured during the seizure.

procedures.name: Poisoning

ingestion: Quickly remove any remaining substance from their mouth.
If the person is conscious and alert, have them rinse out their mouth and sit up.
Call your local poison control center or emergency services immediately for instructions (in the U.S. call 1-800-222-1222).
Follow the specialist’s guidance – do not induce vomiting unless directed.
inhalation: Get the person into fresh air at once.
Check breathing; if absent or labored, call emergency services and begin CPR if needed.
Treat for shock (cover with blanket) if unresponsive.

key_precautions: Do not induce vomiting or give any antidote unless instructed by a professional.
Do not give food/drink unless told.
Avoid contaminating yourself: use gloves/mask if chemical.
Remove the person from the source of poison (e.g. gas leak).
when_to_call_emergency: Call emergency services immediately if the person is unconscious, having trouble breathing, convulsing, or if the poisoning involves a dangerous substance (like household chemicals, medications overdose, carbon monoxide).
Even if not severe, call poison control for guidance.

procedures.name: Bites and Stings
step_by_step_first_aid: For insect stings (bees, wasps): remove stinger by scraping it out (don’t pinch), wash the area, and apply a cold pack to reduce swelling.
For bites or stings by poisonous insects/spiders (scorpion, etc.), clean the wound, cover it with a loose bandage, and apply cold compress.
For snakebites or other venomous bites, keep the person still and calm, with the bite below heart level if possible.
Wash skin around bite (not venom itself) and cover with dry dressing.
Seek help urgently.
key_precautions: Do not suck out venom, cut the wound, or apply a tourniquet.
Do not apply ice or heat to venomous bites (ice may be used for bee stings swelling only).
Keep the bitten limb immobilized and try to minimize movement.
when_to_call_emergency: Call emergency services for any snakebite or if there are systemic signs (difficulty breathing, swelling beyond bite, nausea).
Call if an allergic reaction occurs (see “Allergic Reactions” below).
If the animal is unknown or has rabies risk (see “Animal Bites” next), seek immediate help.

procedures.name: Allergic Reactions (Anaphylaxis)
step_by_step_first_aid: If a known allergic person is showing signs of anaphylaxis (hives, swelling of face/tongue, difficulty breathing), inject epinephrine immediately (e.g. use their EpiPen auto-injector in the outer thigh as instructed).
Have them lie down with legs elevated (unless breathing is difficult, then keep upright).
Administer a second dose of epinephrine after 5–10 minutes if symptoms worsen and no improvement.
key_precautions: Do not wait – severe allergic reactions require immediate epinephrine and EMS.
Be ready to manage airway (if throat swelling, anaphylaxis can block airway).
Have CPR ready in case of collapse.
After injecting, hold the injector firmly against thigh for 3 seconds and massage area.
when_to_call_emergency: Always call emergency services immediately for anaphylaxis (even after using epinephrine).
If the person cannot inject themselves or there is any doubt, call EMS.
Anaphylaxis can progress rapidly, so professional help is critical.

procedures.name: Asthma Attack
step_by_step_first_aid: Help the person sit upright and stay calm.

If they have a quick-relief inhaler (bronchodilator), assist them in using it: shake the inhaler, attach a spacer if available, have them exhale fully, then inhale slowly while pressing the inhaler (2 puffs, 1 minute apart).
Encourage slow breaths and rest.
If no improvement after the first dose, give up to a total of 3 doses as directed.
key_precautions: Do not panic the person.
Ensure they do not overuse the inhaler beyond directions.
Keep track of how many doses given.
when_to_call_emergency: Call emergency services if they do not improve after 1–2 inhaler doses, or if they become very breathless, are too short of breath to speak, or show bluish lips.
Also call if this is their first severe attack.

procedures.name: Diabetic Emergencies

hypoglycemia_low_blood_sugar: If the person is conscious and able to swallow, give about 15–20 grams of quick-acting carbohydrate (for example, 4 ounces of juice or regular soda, glucose tablets/gel, or candy).
Recheck after 10–15 minutes and repeat if needed.
If they have glucagon and someone trained, assist in giving it if they stop responding.
hyperglycemia_high_blood_sugar: If they are alert, encourage them to drink water.
They may need insulin, but only administer if they are trained to do so.

key_precautions: Do not give sugar if the person is unconscious or unable to swallow (they could choke). Instead, place them in recovery position and call EMS.
Do not give any food or drink if unconscious.
If you are unsure whether blood sugar is high or low, it is safer to treat for low by giving sugar.
when_to_call_emergency: Call emergency services if the person is unconscious, having a seizure, or cannot swallow.
If you gave sugar and there is no improvement after 10–15 minutes, or if you suspect dangerously high blood sugar (DKA) with vomiting or dehydration, seek medical help.
Call if no recovery or if you cannot wake them.

procedures.name: Drowning
step_by_step_first_aid: Do not put yourself at risk; only rescue if safe.
Once the person is out of the water, immediately check responsiveness and breathing.
If not breathing, call emergency services at once (if alone, give 1–2 minutes of CPR first).
Begin CPR with rescue breaths: give 5 initial breaths (head tilt, pinch nose), then proceed with chest compressions (30 compressions).
Alternate 30 compressions/2 breaths and continue until the person breathes or EMS arrives.
key_precautions: Keep airway open (be ready to clear water from mouth).
After each CPR cycle, check for signs of life.
Once breathing returns, place them in the recovery position and treat for shock/hypothermia (cover with blanket).
when_to_call_emergency: Always call emergency services for any drowning incident, even if the person seems to recover.
If the person is rescued but conscious and breathing, still seek medical evaluation (secondary drowning and hypothermia can occur).

procedures.name: Nosebleeds
step_by_step_first_aid: Have the person sit down and lean forwards (to prevent swallowing blood).
Keep the head above heart level.
Ask them to pinch the soft part of the nose (just below the bony bridge) firmly with thumb and index finger for 10–15 minutes without letting go.
Breathe through the mouth.
After 10–15 minutes, check if bleeding has stopped; if not, pinch another 5–10 minutes.
key_precautions: Do not tilt the head back or lie down (to avoid blood going down throat).
Do not pack tissue deep into the nose.
If the person has taken blood thinners, bruise easily, or has high blood pressure, be especially gentle.
when_to_call_emergency: Seek help if bleeding is very heavy (filling more than half a soda can), lasts longer than 20–30 minutes despite pressure, or if accompanied by facial injury or signs of head trauma.
Also call if the person feels faint, or if bleeding recurs repeatedly.

procedures.name: Eye Injuries
step_by_step_first_aid: For a small foreign object in the eye, instruct the person to blink; flush the eye with clean water or saline (cup an eye with a glass of water or use an eyewash).
Gently lift eyelids (lower and upper) to try to dislodge debris.
Remove contact lenses if possible before rinsing.
For a chemical splash, immediately flush the eye continuously with lukewarm water for at least 20 minutes (while retracting eyelids) and then seek emergency care.
For a blow or penetration, apply a loose eye shield (a paper cup) and do not press on the eye.
key_precautions: Do not rub the eye.
Do not attempt to remove embedded objects (seek help).
Do not apply any medication (except the flush).
Do not stop irrigation early if chemical injury – continue full 20 minutes.
when_to_call_emergency: Immediately seek medical help if an object is embedded or cannot be flushed out, if vision is impaired, or if the injury is due to a chemical (after flushing).
Any eye cut or deep scratch also needs prompt care.

procedures.name: Head Injuries
step_by_step_first_aid: If the person has a head injury, keep them still and lying down with shoulders slightly raised.
Control any bleeding with gentle pressure (except avoid pressure over a suspected skull fracture).
Check breathing and responsiveness; if they stop breathing, begin CPR.
key_precautions: Do not move the person’s head or neck (tie or tape a rolled towel beside neck if spine injury is possible).
Do not remove a helmet if wearing one (unless needed to provide CPR).
Do not put a pillow under the head.
Monitor closely for changes: repeated vomiting, worsening headache, confusion or drowsiness.
when_to_call_emergency: Call emergency services if the person is unconscious, has any of the following: severe headache, repeated vomiting, seizures, weakness or numbness, unequal pupils, slurred speech, or fluid/blood from nose or ears.
Also call if they simply do not wake up or any concussion symptoms worsen.

procedures.name: Spinal Injuries
step_by_step_first_aid: If a spinal injury is suspected (neck/back pain after trauma, tingling, paralysis), do not move the person.
Immobilize the head and neck in the position found (support head with towels or hands).
Call emergency services immediately.
key_precautions: Never twist or bend the spine.
Keep them still and wait for professional help.
If an injured person must be moved (dangerous location), do a log-roll with help, keeping spine straight.
If the person is unconscious but breathing, maintain airway with jaw-thrust without tilting the head.
when_to_call_emergency: Any suspected spinal injury is a medical emergency – call immediately.
Signs include severe neck/back pain, deformity, numbness or paralysis in limbs, altered consciousness, or after any major trauma.

procedures.name: Animal Bites (Mammals)
step_by_step_first_aid: Clean the bite wound thoroughly with soap and water to flush out bacteria.
Apply gentle pressure if bleeding, and then cover with a clean, dry bandage.
If it’s a minor bite (no deep puncture), apply an antibiotic ointment before bandaging.
key_precautions: Avoid closing the wound if it may be infected (fresh bites may be left open and covered).
Do not ignore pet bites; they can easily become infected.
when_to_call_emergency: Seek medical care promptly for any deep, puncture, or crushing bite, or if bleeding cannot be controlled.
Also call if swelling, redness, pain increases (infection).
If bitten by a wild or unknown animal (risk of rabies), or if the person’s tetanus shot is not up-to-date, get medical help immediately.

procedures.name: Electrical Injuries
step_by_step_first_aid: Do not touch the person if they are still in contact with electricity.
Turn off the power source at once.
If not possible, move the source away with a non-conductive object (wood, plastic).
Once safe, check responsiveness.
If the person is unresponsive, not breathing or has no pulse, call emergency services and begin CPR immediately.
Cover any electrical burns with a dry, sterile dressing (do not use wet or loose materials).
key_precautions: Stay away from wires or the source.
Keep onlookers clear.
Do not attempt to cool electrical burns (they may be deep).
Watch for cardiac arrest – electricity can stop the heart silently.
when_to_call_emergency: Always call emergency services for any significant electrical shock or burn.
Signs to call: any loss of consciousness, breathing difficulty, abnormal heart rhythm, or large burns.
Even if the person seems fine (especially with high-voltage or lightning injury), medical evaluation is needed.

procedures.name: Foreign Objects in Eyes, Nose, or Throat

eye: If a small particle is in the eye, flush with clean water or saline while the person leans over a sink.
Have them blink or pull the eyelids to try to dislodge it.
If not removed or if irritation persists, seek medical care.
nose: If something is lodged in the nose, have the person blow their nose gently with mouth open.
If an object is visible near the nostril, you may carefully remove it with tweezers (only if it’s soft and easily grasped).
For a nosebleed with object, follow nosebleed care (see above).
throat: For an object in the throat causing choking, follow the choking procedures above.
If the person is not choking but feels something stuck (like fish bone), do not try to grab it blindly; sip water or cough it out.

key_precautions: Do not blindly probe the eye or nostril with fingers or tools; this can push objects deeper.
Do not induce vomiting for throat objects.
Keep calm and avoid panicking the person.
when_to_call_emergency: Seek medical help if you cannot remove the object, or if the person has trouble breathing, severe pain, or persistent bleeding.
For eye objects that cannot be flushed out or any eye pain/vision change, call for help.
If a nasal foreign body cannot be expelled and the person is in distress, or if a throat object causes breathing difficulty, call emergency services.

source_information: Authoritative first-aid resources including the American and British Red Cross, Mayo Clinic, NHS and others (each section cites specific guidelines)
